videos.title: The best stats you've ever seen

highlights.title: Host Sets the Stage
highlights.label: Talk Setup
highlights.note: The TED host frames Hans Rosling's presentation as a transformative look at global data, priming viewers for evidence-based insights.

highlights.title: Hans' Data-Driven Promise
highlights.label: Mission
highlights.note: Hans promises to show the world through statistics instead of anecdotes, positioning the talk as a visual data journey.

highlights.title: 120,000 Data Points
highlights.label: Scope
highlights.note: He cites the 120,000 UN data points behind the demo, underscoring the rigor underpinning the visualization.

highlights.title: Chart Legend Explained
highlights.label: Legend
highlights.note: Axes, colors, and bubble sizes are decoded—child survival, family size, continent, and population—so the audience can read the story.

highlights.title: 1962 Two-World Snapshot
highlights.label: 1962 Baseline
highlights.note: The static 1962 view reveals a stark split between nations with large families and low child survival and those with the opposite, mirroring the era's 'developed vs. developing' narrative.

highlights.title: Bridging Regions
highlights.label: Bridging Regions
highlights.note: Hans points out Middle Eastern and Latin American countries already crossing the gap, complicating a simple rich/poor divide.

highlights.title: East Asia's Starting Point
highlights.label: East Asia
highlights.note: East Asian nations begin with large families but noticeably higher child survival than much of Africa, hinting at the surge to come.

highlights.title: Let the World Run
highlights.label: Global Shift
highlights.note: When Hans starts the animation, bubbles sweep toward smaller families and healthier children, signalling a worldwide demographic transition.

highlights.title: Latin America's Curve
highlights.label: Latin America
highlights.note: Latin American countries trace a steady curve toward low fertility while sustaining child survival gains, evidencing rapid modernization.

highlights.title: East Asian Tigers Surge
highlights.label: Tigers
highlights.note: Japan, South Korea, Singapore, and peers rocket across the chart, embodying how investment in health and education accelerates development.

highlights.title: China's Leap Forward
highlights.label: China
highlights.note: China's bubble accelerates after economic reforms, coupling steep fertility decline with dramatic gains in child survival.

highlights.title: African Progress & Setbacks
highlights.label: Africa View
highlights.note: Sub-Saharan bubbles inch upward yet lag behind, and Hans notes how HIV and conflict can bend trajectories despite overall improvement.

highlights.title: Country Drilldown
highlights.label: Country Focus
highlights.note: Zooming in on specific African nations, Hans shows how health policies shift individual paths even when income stays low.

highlights.title: Cultural Myth Busting
highlights.label: Myths
highlights.note: Highlighting Muslim-majority countries, he debunks cultural myths by charting rapid fertility drops alongside investments in education and healthcare.

highlights.title: Retiring 'Developing World'
highlights.label: New Narrative
highlights.note: Hans concludes the opening segment by arguing the data renders 'developing world' obsolete because convergence is now the dominant pattern.
